page.title: 11PHEASANT REARING-GILLING W.
page.content: Hen pheasants start laying their eggs in April or May and can lay up to 50. In the wild, only about 6-10 hatch out but hand- reared pheasants usually hatch 75% or more.They then go out at day old chicks or are reared on by the pheasant farmer until they are 6 weeks old. As day old chicks they start on pheasant crumbs (very fine pellets)and by the time they come to be released at 6-8 weeks old they will be on larger pellets mixed with wheat. As tiny chicks they need plenty of heat on them and gas lamps are usually used.The heat is reduced as they grow, until at 4-5 weeks none is needed. The pheasants go into a release pen at 6-8 weeks,when they can fly out and find food. They are flying free by October when the shooting season starts.
